org.javact.compiler
Class Message

java.lang.Object
  org.javact.compiler.Message
Direct Known Subclasses:
AsynchronousMessage, SynchronousMessage
abstract class Message
extends java.lang.Object

Provides methods for processing the generation of message handling java files.
A Message object is described by:

  • its name: this is the name of the method declared in a behavior interface;
  • its return type: this is the return type of the method. If the return type is void the message is an asynchronous message (see AsynchronousMessage); otherwise it is a synchronous message (see SynchronousMessage).
  • a list of signatures which represent the possible formal parameters for the method. When the method is overloaded this list contains more than one element.

During the processing of behavior profiles, when a couple <method name> + <return type> is encountered for the first time, a new Message instance is created. Afterwards the signature is just added to the message's list of signatures (see addSignature(java.lang.reflect.Method, java.lang.Class)).

This class is composed of a static part interfacing with the compiler's other classes. It is the same structure as in BehaviorProfile.

Version:
0.5.0
Author:
Vincent Hennebert

Field Detail

name

java.lang.String name
Name of the message. Should be accessed only by subclasses.

messageClassName

protected java.lang.String messageClassName
Name of the java Class that will implement the handling of this message. Should be accessed only by subclasses. See getMessageClassName().

signaturesList

protected java.util.List signaturesList
List of all the different signatures of this message. Should be accessed only by subclasses.

Constructor Detail

Message

Message(java.lang.reflect.Method method,
        java.lang.Class owningBehavInterface)
Creates a new Message object corresponding to the given method.

Parameters:
method - the method corresponding to the message.
owningBehavInterface - the behavior interface declaring this message.
Method Detail

addMessage

static Message addMessage(java.lang.reflect.Method method,
                          java.lang.Class owningInterface)
Add the message to the collection of existing messages.

Parameters:
method - the corresponding method.
owningInterface - the BehaviorProfile interface declaring the given method.
Returns:
the corresponding Message instance.

areMessagesToGenerate

static boolean areMessagesToGenerate()
Returns true if there are messages to be generated. It may not be the case when no behavior profile contains messages or when programs were compiled with the –d option but the corresponding directory was not added in the CLASSPATH.

generateMessages

static java.util.List generateMessages()
Generates the message handling java files.

Returns:
String list of filenames corresponding to the generated files.
See Also:
generate()

getMessageClassName

abstract java.lang.String getMessageClassName()
Returns the name of the class that will implement the handling of this message. If it is an asynchronous message it will just be the name of the message. Otherwise the name of the return type will also be appended to the message name.

Returns:
the name of the message handling class.

getMessageFileName

java.lang.String getMessageFileName()
Returns the name of the file that will contain this class handling this message. It is simply the result of getMessageClassName() with the string ".java" added.

Returns:
the filename correspondig to this message.

addSignature

void addSignature(java.lang.reflect.Method _signature,
                  java.lang.Class _owningBehavInterface)
Adds the given signature to the list of already known signatures. If this message already contains the given signature, the behavior interface will simply be added to the signature's set of known behavior interfaces. Otherwise a new Signature instance will be created.

Parameters:
_signature - the method whose signature has to be added.
_owningBehavInterface - the behavior interface declaring the given method.
See Also:
Signature

printClassDeclaration

protected abstract void printClassDeclaration(java.io.PrintWriter out)
Prints out the line "public class <message name> implements..." in the given stream. This line depends on whether the message is asynchronous or synchronous, thus this method is an abstract method that is implemented in the Message subclasses (and should only be accessed by those ones).
If the message is synchronous, this method also prints out the declaration of the field that will contain the result of an invocation of this message.

Parameters:
out - the stream pointing to the file that will contain the message handling class.

printCall

abstract void printCall(java.io.PrintWriter out,
                        java.lang.String behavInterfName,
                        java.lang.String argsList)
Prints out the call to the method implementing this message, declared by the given behavior interface, and owning the given parameters. This call depends on whether the message is asynchronous or synchronous, thus this method is an abstract method that is implemented in the Message subclasses.
In case of a synchronous message, the getServerSideAnswerBack().setReply line also is printed out.
This method is invoked by Signature.printInvoke(java.io.PrintWriter, int), as the Signature instance does not want to know whether its owning message is synchronous or asynchronous.

Parameters:
out - the stream pointing to the file that will contain the message handling class.
behavInterfName - the name of the behavior interface that declares such a message.
argsList - the real parameters of the method (that is its signature).
See Also:
Signature.printInvoke(java.io.PrintWriter, int)

printEndOfGeneration

protected abstract void printEndOfGeneration(java.io.PrintWriter out)
Finishes the generation of the message handling class. In case of a synchronous message the getReply method still has to be printed out.
The stream is closed within this method.
This method should only be accessed by subclasses.

Parameters:
out - the stream that will be printed out.
